required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Supporting Smoke-Free Policy Compliance in Public Housing
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial to Support Smoke-Free Policy Compliance in Public Housing

brief_summary.textblock:
Smoke-free housing policies in multiunit housing are promising and increasingly widespread interventions to reduce smoking and secondhand smoke exposure. Little research has identified factors that improve compliance with smoke-free housing policies in low-income multiunit housing and test corresponding solutions.
The proposed RCT addresses key gaps in knowledge and capitalizes on key scientific opportunities by: 1) leveraging the federal mandate to ban smoking in a public housing system of more than sufficient size to conduct an adequately powered RCT; 2) expanding our understanding of smoke-free policy compliance beyond policy implementation by testing two novel treatments: a) in-residence smoking cessation and b) resident endorsement, while 3) addressing population and location-specific tobacco-related disparities.
The investigators hypothesize that the relocation/cessation plus resident endorsement intervention will yield significantly larger reductions in personal smoking and secondhand smoke exposure, compared to standalone interventions and the standard approach.

detailed_description.textblock:
Introduction The broad objective of this study is to address this gap in knowledge by conducting a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of resident-centered interventions that support smoke-free housing policy compliance in public housing communities. The study will evaluate the effects of much needed compliance support interventions on smoking and secondhand smoke outcomes in randomly selected NYCHA buildings. To date, no RCTs have been conducted in public housing to test the effects of compliance strategies on resident smoking behavior and secondhand smoke exposure despite tobacco-related health disparities.
During the pre-intervention phase, key informant interviews (n=20) and focus groups with 6-8 residents in 8 non-study NYCHA buildings will be conducted to probe for recommended changes in the physical and social environments of the building including designated smoking areas and the information and support needed to support the implementation of the smoke-free policy. Building walkthroughs will also be conducted at baseline and follow-ups to record signs of active smoking and/or tobacco/marijuana odor. Initial baseline assessments salivary cotinine concentrations as well as questionnaires will be administered to study participants in order to establish baseline data before interventions.
Participant contact will be done face-to-face with systematic questionnaires and potentially identifying information will be asked or recorded for study participants (although NO birthdates, photos, or video recordings, will be taken of participants). Consent to participate in the study will be asked before the actual study begins and individuals who refuse will not take part in the study. The investigators will simply explain the study, its intent, its burden, and ask if the investigators can proceed. Informed consent documents and study materials will be translated (forward and back translated) and administered in Spanish where needed. All identifying information for each participant will be destroyed at the conclusion of the study.
Waiver of written documentation of informed consent has been obtained through the Columbia University Medical Center IRB. The research presents no more than minimal risk of harm to subjects and involves no procedures for which written consent is normally required outside of the research context. A waiver of documentation of consent is appropriate, because the only link between the subject and the study would be the consent document and the primary risk is a breach of confidentiality.
The investigators will establish excellent rapport with respondents and assure them that the investigators are researchers with a private, local university and in no way representing law enforcement or government agencies. No analyses, reports, or peer-reviewed articles will identify any participants.
The investigators will record information about the participant during initial participant recruitment that will allow us to recontact that same individual for follow-up surveys at 3 and 12-months post- intervention. With the participant's consent, this information may include address and/or telephone number so that the investigators can recontact them to schedule subsequent follow-up. Participants will also be informed that any other identifying information that is recorded - such as names, birthdates, etc. -will be destroyed at the conclusion of the study.
Study interventions will be assessed at 3- and 12-months following baseline. Once buildings are screened for participation, buildings will be assigned codes for purposes of evaluation. All questionnaires and data collection protocols will be adapted from established questionnaires and protocols used in tobacco control and public housing research and will be pilot tested.
In addition to baseline data collected on building characteristics through KI interviews and initial walkthroughs, a walkthrough will also be conducted at the final 12-month, in-person assessment period.. The presence of cigarettes, cigars, ashtrays with/out ashes, matches or lighters will be documented within apartments and around the building premises including stairwells, elevators, hallways, laundry rooms, in/outdoor community spaces, playgrounds and the perimeter of the buildings.
The investigators will use mobile devices to monitor of evidence of smoking or secondhand smoke. The team will make notes about visual evidence (cigarette butts, wrappers) or sight or smell of smoking behavior. Other issues in/around the building such as trash, holes in the walls or floors, broken stair railings, loitering, loud music and quality of life concerns will be recorded to document other issues that contribute to general non-compliance with building rules.
Individual Questionnaires: Questionnaires will capture smoking behavior among smokers and secondhand smoke exposure among non-smokers. Specifically, questionnaires will include questions about sociodemographic data (age, sex, race/ethnicity, education), time spent at home, smoking history (including use of cigarettes, marijuana and other tobacco products e.g. waterpipes and e-cigarettes, and photos of cigarette packs and tobacco products used by smokers), and secondhand smoke exposure (including exposure duration at different public and private indoor and outdoor environments), a brief medical history, and exposure to tobacco control measures such as cessation services, smoke-free interventions and tobacco marketing and promotion. The investigators will also ask participants to indicate where they smoke, interest in quitting smoking and if/when they plan to quit. Crucially, questionnaires will also include questions about participant involvement in or exposure to NYCHA's smoke-free programming, including interactions with NYCHA Smoke-Free Liaisons. Questionnaires will be administered to participants in each arm at baseline, follow-up and final assessment.
Salivary Collection / Self-Report: Baseline and 12-month final assessment Exposure to smoke either directly among smokers or indirectly through secondhand smoke will be assessed through self-report and salivary collection. A self-report questionnaire will be administered to assess any exposure in the last week. Self-report has been demonstrated to be a reliable method for assessing exposure. The investigators will randomize whether participants will partake in salivary collection. For 25% of participants, saliva will be collected at baseline and at 12 months via passive drool collection. Saliva cotinine will be measured at the Columbia University Biomarker Core Laboratory using cotinine ELISA Kits (Salimetrics, State College, PA). The Salimetrics ELISA kit is an enzyme immunoassay used to measure primary or secondhand exposure to nicotine via cotinine. It is not intended for diagnostic use. It is intended only for research use among humans and some animals. The assay is non-invasive, involves no genetic sequencing, and is not used as a diagnostic procedure.
Data Analysis Procedures Qualitative Data Analysis: Focus group and key informant interview transcripts will be analyzed as textual data along with the visual data and fieldnotes from the sensory inspections using ATLAS.ti. At least two members of the research team will engage in a two-phase inductive analytical process informed by phenomenology. The first phase of analysis will involve "open coding" in which all transcripts and visual documents will be coded based on a descriptive assessment of the information appearing in the data. A codebook will be subsequently developed that outlines and defines each code; the data will be reanalyzed to systematically apply codes from the codebook and identify emergent topics that characterize and explain the nature of smoking in the buildings. The second phase will entail "axial coding" in which the codes will be thematically grouped and patterns in the data will be assessed to reflect causal relationships, contextual factors, intervening conditions, strategies and consequences. This preliminary phase will help refine subsequent resident engagement and data collection efforts, and intervention protocols as done previously.
Statistical Analysis: The investigators will conduct intent-to-treat (ITT) and contamination-adjusted intention-to-treat (CA-ITT) analyses to estimate the effects of the smoking relocation/cessation and resident endorsement interventions compared to the standard program implemented by NYCHA (no treatment). CA-ITT analyses will account for unanticipated contamination between trial arms and be completed via two-stage instrumental variables regressions using the original random allocation codes per assigned unit. Preliminary data analysis will include examination of distribution and summary statistics of all variables by intervention groups at each time point. The continuous variables with skewed distribution will be properly transformed, if necessary, to reduce impact of extreme values or improve model fitting. The investigators will use box-plots to examine how distribution of a quantitative variable varies by categories of a categorical variable, and use scatter plots and Spearman correlation coefficient to examine bivariate associations between quantitative variables. Chi-square and Kruskal-Wallis tests will be used to detect group differences in categorical and quantitative baseline variables, respectively. For successful randomization, the investigators expect no difference in the distribution of all baseline variables among the four arms. The baseline variables that differ by intervention groups and are related to outcomes of interest will be controlled in the aim specific models.
Aim-specific analysis: The investigators will use generalized linear models with repeated measures (GLMRM) for each aim where outcome variables may have different form (continuous, binary or count) and the measurements are likely to be correlated due to residing in the same building or being from the same participant over time. The investigators will use the generalized estimation equation method to estimate model parameters and make statistical inference since it takes into account intra-cluster (within-building or within-person) correlations and uses all available data.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The proposed design will be a borough-stratified, four-arm, factorial-design, cluster RCT that will target 64 randomly selected buildings (16 buildings per arm) in separate NYCHA developments. We will recruit and follow 8 randomly selected residents stratified by smoking status- 4 smokers and 4 non-smokers- per building (n=512 residents) into four arms: (1) relocation/cessation, (2) resident endorsement, (3) relocation/cessation plus resident endorsement and (4) the standard approach (128 participants per arm).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in number of cigarettes smoked per day
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline (in person interview), 3 months (phone interview) and 12 months (in person interview)
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported average number of cigarettes smoked per day among smokers

primary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and at the 12-month follow-up
primary_outcome.description: Salivary cotinine (saliva collected as passive drool) will be measured for 25% of the sample among smokers and non-smokers alike

primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline (in person interview), 3 months (phone interview) and 12 months (in person interview)
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported secondhand smoking exposure (hours of secondhand smoke exposure in the building in the past 7 days); among smokers & non-smokers

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in number of participants with successful quit attempts
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline (in person interview), 3 months (phone interview) and 12 months (in person interview)
secondary_outcome.description: Binary; whether smokers have successfully quit

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in number of quit attempts
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline (in person interview), 3 months (phone interview) and 12 months (in person interview)
secondary_outcome.description: Mean number of quitting attempts among smokers

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with secondhand smoke observations
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Ever observing someone smoking indoors within the past 7 days
secondary_outcome.description: Binary; whether participant has observed someone smoking indoors in the building; among smokers & non-smokers

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of hours of secondhand smoke exposure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Number of hours observed someone smoking indoors within the past 7 days
secondary_outcome.description: Counted number of hours of exposure

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At each building visit at baseline and 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: Counted number of people observed smoking in common areas

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in number of cigarette butts
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At each building visit at baseline and 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: Counted number of cigarette butts observed in common areas

arm_group.description: Smokers will be referred by the survey team to Community Outreach Workers (COWs) trained to address the heath care needs of underserved populations providing medical care and services, including tobacco cessation. The COW will coordinate smoking cessation support, including serving as a liaison between participant and research team, providing information regarding the smoke-free policy and opportunities for relocation, and connecting participant to access to tobacco replacement therapy and/or physician support if deemed appropriate.

Buildings assigned will be targeted for a series of 2 in-residence programs that involve community forums and the creative arts to garner resident endorsements of smoke-free living environments. Premised on resident engagement, this arm seeks to impact social and physical dimensions of the residential environment to achieve compliance. The sessions will: 1) inform residents of risks associated with smoking and secondhand smoke; 2) identify reasons to have a smoke-free home, 3) ask residents to sign a pledge on paper and/or virtually; 4) display smoke-free signage on doors and/or social media pages with an original hashtag (#Smokefree[building address]); and 5) refer residents to the Smoke-free NYCHA website for information on the policy and existing cessation resources.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Compliance through relocation/cessation plus resident endorsement (combined)
arm_group.description: The combined intervention will be carried out in the buildings assigned to this RCT arm, which will provide in-residence programs based on the resident endorsement treatment and the smoking relocation/cessation treatment. Both will occur simultaneously with one geared toward all building residents (resident endorsement) and the other targeting smokers (smoking relocation/cessation) with the goal of reducing both personal smoking and secondhand smoke exposure.

Buildings and study participants assigned to this arm will be recruited and followed over a 12-month period to assess outcomes. No additional programs or services will be delivered to the buildings or residents assigned to this arm beyond standard programs that NYCHA may provide to support the smoke-free mandate. Field staff will document any policy-related signage, activities or information to which these participants are exposed.

intervention.description: Individual-level. COW to provide cessation and/or relocation support.
intervention.arm_group_label: Compliance through relocation/cessation plus resident endorsement (combined)

intervention.description: Building-level. COW to conduct building-level sessions.
intervention.arm_group_label: Compliance through relocation/cessation plus resident endorsement (combined)

criteria.textblock:
Focus Group Inclusion Criteria:
- For focus groups, we will recruit NYCHA residents via door knocking and lobby intercepts. We will differentiate eligibility by smoker or non-smoker and maintain database information collected from focus group participants so as not to contaminate interventions by recruiting the same participants later.
Focus Group Exclusion Criteria:
- None
Building Inclusion Criteria:
- NYCHA buildings in Manhattan & the Bronx (stratified evenly by borough) with more than 50 units, not undergoing major renovations.
- Randomization: In each borough, 8 buildings will be randomly assigned to receive one of the 4 intervention arms. Dr. Valeri, the study biostatistician, will generate the randomization list and inform the investigators to which arm each building has been randomized once eligibility for participation has been confirmed, the baseline data and interviews have been completed, and the building and investigators are ready to begin in each building.
Building Exclusion Criteria:
- Buildings in a borough that is not in Manhattan or the Bronx
- Buildings smaller than 50 units
- Buildings undergoing major renovations
Participant Inclusion Criteria:
- Recruit NYCHA residents via door knocking and lobby intercepts until we reach our targeted number per group (4 smokers, 4 non-smokers in each building).
- Residents will be screened for smoking status. Both smokers and non-smokers to be recruited but only one participant- smoker or a non-smoker- will be recruited per apartment.
- Smoking will be defined as those that report using a cigarette or other combustible tobacco product (e.g., little cigar, cigarillo) at least 5 days in the past month. Non-smokers include never smokers and former smokers who had quit 12 months ago or earlier.
- Additional eligibility criteria include individuals above 18 years old living in the building at least 5 days/week and 9 months/year, not planning on moving in the next 2 years.
Participant Exclusion Criteria:
- We will exclude those with severe physical or mental medical conditions (i.e. cognitive disability) or other factors that could limit participation or ability to give informed consent in the study at baseline or during follow-ups.
- We will also exclude those who participated in the earlier focus groups.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Project Coordinator, Department of Sociomedical Sciences (Interim RP)

patient_data.ipd_description: Data from approximately 512 participants will be released to sponsor (NIH) once the final dataset is analyzed and main findings are accepted for publication to support and validate study findings. This will include participant demographics, qualitative data from interviews, and laboratory data from saliva samples. Identifiers might be removed from the identifiable private information or identifiable biospecimens and that, after such removal, the information or biospecimens could be used for future research studies without additional consent from the subject. De-identified participant data may be utilized for the purposes of repeated analyses by other researchers to verify findings, and/or to promote further research with new or alternative hypotheses. The mechanism of distribution will be a data sharing agreement.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Data will be available once the final dataset is analyzed and main findings are accepted for publication to support and validate study findings. Access will be granted for researchers, institutions, and/or the broader public for as long as the data is anticipated to be useful. With the data sharing agreement in mind, the data can be made available for the duration of time needed to conduct analyses.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Access should be granted to those with a reputable background in the scientific field who have either a scientific or medical degree and/or a relevant position to ask for the data. Individuals should also express their intended use of the data. These requests will be routinely reviewed by the principal investigator [and/or designated team member].
